Not trying to be a know-it-all, but just thought this may interest you. REM sleep is actually one of the lightest sleep stages. Stages 3-4 are your slow wave sleep stages and the deepest stages of sleep. The brain cycles through different stages throughout the night, but after leaving stage 1 rather than returning back to stage 1 it goes into REM sleep. This is total speculation, but it could be that since REM is inhibited you spend more time in the slower wave sleep stages when smoking weed

Oh for sure it's important. Yeah in REM sleep you get brain waves similar to beta waves, which are the same waves you have when you are awake and somewhat alert. So it could stand to reason that if REM is inhibited then you'll stay in stages 2-4 longer and feel more rested. Who knows for sure tho, the brain is weird and as you said REM is definitely still important. Anyway hope I didn't come off as a know it all, I just find this stuff interesting and wanted to give my .02$

WRITING.TITLE: What happens to all the animals in the meat/dairy industries if everyone were to go vegan?
WRITING.TEXT: This is more of a question and less of a debate prompt, so apologies if this is the wrong place to post. It just seemed to be too heated to post on r/askvegans. So what I #8217;m wondering is if there are any achievable ideas on how to handle all these animals if they are no longer being slaughtered/milked for food. Obviously we couldn #8217;t just release them all as that would destroy ecosystems and their populations would likely explode. I also heavily doubt that a vegan would agree to just slaughtering all remaining animals in the industries for food and not breeding them anymore. Additionally, some of these animals are dependent on humans to prevent them from suffering. Holstein cows, for example, have been selectively bred to produce way more milk than their calves need, and are in pain when they are not milked regularly. Would we continue to milk them to reduce suffering but just not consume the milk, effectively wasting it? Would we just keep these animals alive and comfortable and prevent them from reproducing to phase out their variant? Would it even be ethical to phase out variants of cows that don #8217;t suffer like Holsteins, but are also no longer needed by humans and have no place in nature? To clarify I mean they were bred for captivity and they don #8217;t belong in any natural ecosystems, but is it right to prevent them from reproducing and just let them disappear when the last one dies? There is a staggering number of these animals in farms/slaughterhouses around the world, and many of them are dependent on humans. What would be the most possible and humane way to deal with them if they are no longer being eaten? TLDR: basically the title is what I #8217;m asking. Everything else is just points regarding the question that make it difficult for me to answer.

I fully agree with strict background checks, although the checks aren #8217;t bad rn and a lot of guns used in crimes are unregistered. Biden has supported assault weapon bans in the past (source: https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.nytimes.com/2019/08/11/opinion/joe-biden-ban-assault-weapons.amp.html). It #8217;s a slow process to remove guns from the public, so they are targeting assault weapons first and will then target hunting rifles and large caliber handguns. It will be easy to convince people a pistol that fires .50 action express once a rifle firing a little 5.56 has been banned. Biden also said he would put Beto O #8217;Rourke in charge of gun control (source: https://billofrightsinstitute.org/events/joe-biden-promises-to-put-beto-orourke-in-charge-of-gun-control/). And if you don #8217;t know, Beto said he would absolutely take our AR-15s and AK-47s. (https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.cnn.com/cnn/2019/09/12/politics/beto-orourke-hell-yes-take-ar-15-ak-47/index.html). This is all just to say, Biden absolutely wants to take guns away despite his outspoken anti-confiscation policies. All of the left wants to disarm the public. Look at all our recent police killings on innocent people, doesn #8217;t it seem unreasonable to disarm these people if the government is actively killing them? And not to mention the criminals. I #8217;ll say it again, banning guns is near impossible in America and removing them will just increase the government #8217;s and the criminals #8217; power. Australia is a totally different story. Prior to the port Arthur massacre in 1996 when all the legislation was passed banning firearms, there were 3.2 million privately owned firearms (by civilians). In 2016 there are now 3.15m firearms privately owned by civilians. Not a large decrease but there are differences in the types of guns owned. But my point is mostly that trying to control 3.2 million firearms is completely different from controlling 393 million firearms in America. (Source for the figures: https://www.gunpolicy.org/firearms/region/australia) They are different issues and require different solutions, and honestly I #8217;m not sure what those solutions might be. Stricter background checks seems like the way to go, but they can only get so strict. Some people really are perfect on paper but crack and decide to kill people. Also there is the issue that the right to arm yourself is in our constitution, so any severe act of power from the government to remove guns from the public could spark a civil war. It #8217;s a complex issue and unfortunately I don #8217;t think copying Australia will fix it.

What if there were some people who did bad things by today #8217;s standards but were also heroes in the past? I #8217;m from Texas, so I #8217;ll use Tx history as an example. Stephen F. Austin and James Bowie both promoted slavery. This was accepted back then and part of their norm. Despite them having messed up views about slavery, they still were still Texas heroes and that can #8217;t be taken away from them. Bowie was an absolute badass and his name is still important due to the creation of the Bowie knife. I like to see those statues of them when I visit Texas museums or the Alamo. Also, some American legends were complicit in slavery but also promoted abolition. Ulysses S Grant comes to mind. Grant was a freaking Union general, he fought for the emancipation proclamation. But since he owned slaves we shouldn #8217;t honor his history? And George Washington #8217;s amazing leadership and sharp brain kind of speak for themselves, we should still honor him despite him owning slaves. It #8217;s important to realize how normalized slavery was, it was terrible, but people like Washington held a totally different frame of mind than what we have today. I #8217;ll always respect people like George Washington even if they did own slaves, they are multifaceted. I don #8217;t respect him for owning slaves, but I do for everything else he did.

WRITING.TITLE: Developing an aversion to animal products.
WRITING.TEXT: I #8217;m just curious if any of you became vegan not necessarily due to the morality and ethics of it, but because you simply developed an aversion to animal products? This started happening to me around the beginning of the year, and it #8217;s getting worse and worse. I used to be happy that I was such a non-picky eater. But the thought of eating meat and cheese (and recently, increasingly eggs and butter) makes me gag these days. I #8217;m not sure what happened. I #8217;m slightly concerned it won #8217;t stop and I #8217;ll develop an aversion to non-animal based food too, as I #8217;m already feeling aversion to things like potatoes and mushrooms. Just wondering if anyone else has had this experience? I #8217;m worried it #8217;s a psychological problem EDIT: Thanks a lot for everyone's advice. I had a feeling this wasn't normal, but figured I'd seek advice in other avenues before seeing a doctor. I'll make an appointment soon to try to rule out any physical issues, and if that comes up clean I'll look at therapists. I hope I can come back and revisit veganism after I work this out, as I think it will be an easier diet for me to follow since animal products absolutely disgust me at this point. Very grateful for all of your advice, best of luck to everyone during the Pandemic.
Thanks, I #8217;ll check in with a doctor.

Thanks for the advice, I figured this might be a heath problem, but hoped it #8217;s not. I #8217;ll check it out and definitely revisit veganism. I can #8217;t imagine I #8217;ll ever be able to eat meat again even if I do get some form of treatment. Imagining eating the fat, sinew, etc. is what #8217;s bothering me. It #8217;s like I #8217;m beginning to fixate on whether the food is #8220;clean #8221; or not. Not sure what a better term than clean is, it doesn #8217;t nail what I #8217;m feeling but it #8217;s the best term I can think of. Same thing with potatoes and mushrooms

I appreciate your advice, everyone seems to suggest I see a doctor. That definitely seems like the right course, just wanted to seek advice elsewhere first. I #8217;ll revisit the idea of going vegan after I find out if there #8217;s something wrong with me

Someone else suggested it might have a physical root. I guess I #8217;ll check there first. I think it #8217;s more psychological, because it #8217;s thinking about the food and I dwell on what it is and whether it #8217;s clean. Like with meat I dwell on how it #8217;s disgusting to eat the fat, sinew, etc. or with potatoes I dwell on that they were covered in dirt, or mushrooms growing in manure. That #8217;s why I #8217;m concerned it could get worse if it spreads to other vegetables since manure is used in a lot of compost. Idk, I would guess it #8217;s psychological in root. I #8217;m in the mood to argue again, and you are very civil unlike most liberals I talk to, so I #8217;m glad to engage. First I #8217;d love to see the video about Trump saying he mislead about the pandemic. Not trying to be the annoying #8220;source please #8221; person, but I #8217;d genuinely be interested to hear it. Regarding the other points, I #8217;d begin by saying masks becoming a political issue was never on Trump. He advocated for masks basically the entire time, tho early on even the media was confused. He didn #8217;t wear masks during his press conferences likely to speak more clearly. Never once did he say masks are bad and people shouldn #8217;t wear them. Now sure, some conservative Karen types decided it was a breach to their freedom, but you can #8217;t blame their opinions on Trump. Now regarding other countries responding better, Trump responded extremely early to the pandemic and went so far as to close off travel from China at the end of January. An action that Democrats vilified, and even in one of the debates every candidate said they wouldn #8217;t do it. As far as us doing worse than other countries, there are two key elements to look at. 1. We do far more testing than any other country, so of course our numbers will be higher. 2. We are a massive country with many more citizens than other countries. It would be more accurate to compare American infection numbers and death rates to the entirety of Europe rather than a single country like Germany. I #8217;m quite sure neither of us will convince the other of their viewpoint, but I like arguing when it doesn #8217;t devolve into ad hominems immediately.

No it #8217;s not, that #8217;s not how the immune system works. The placebo effect cannot cause the immune system to create antibodies against covid. Edit: I suppose it could happen, but it #8217;s insanely unlikely. From what we understand the immune response tries to create antibodies against the pathogen seemingly randomly. So it could be possible for it to create an antibody that would work on covid, without every detecting covid. This would be so unlikely though, it #8217;s nearly impossible.

Yeah that #8217;s true, I #8217;m very aware the placebo effect is no joke as my brother is a biostatistician and I work in a biochemistry lab. I was mostly referring to how OP tested positive for the antibodies, which is very unlikely for the placebo effect to cause. (Essentially impossible it #8217;s so astronomically unlikely)

That #8217;s a good point. OP could #8217;ve gotten placebo but caught covid somewhere else. I was just trying to explain how a placebo would likely never result in covid antibodies (though I won #8217;t say it #8217;s impossible, just so very unlikely to the point it could be assumed impossible)

The point is that placebo could cause the body to work harder and could possibly get extremely lucky and generate an antibody that would work against covid. It #8217;s insanely unlikely, but It #8217;s just not good to use absolutes when discussing things like this that aren #8217;t understood. I mean the current model for immune response suggests that antibodies are produced seemingly randomly until one can defend against the pathogen (though I doubt it #8217;s really random). Your analogy of a placebo allowing you to draw a map of Europe is probably about as likely as a placebo creating an antibody against covid. I just didn #8217;t want to say it #8217;s impossible, because given enough cases (like a googol cases, or some other enormous number, it might happen) EDIT: I just want to say I pretty much only added that because I was sure someone would come in and try to correct me saying it could potentially be possible, but of course people will come in to try to correct me either way lol. Yeah, the thing is nuclear power has a ton of great benefits, and I #8217;d never suggest we abandon the idea of using completely. But there are major issues that must be addressed, one being inability to deal with the waste products (containment is not a long term solution). Another being the potential danger of a failure in a nuclear power plant. And perhaps the most important, the difficulty of separating nuclear power from nuclear weapons. The main hurdle to creating nuclear weapons is obtaining the uranium/plutonium isotopes, so if a country is using nuclear power they can very quickly shift to creating nuclear weapons since they #8217;ll already be enriching the isotopes. I agree with OP that nuclear energy can be a game changer, but you #8217;ve gotta look at the potential dangers, including the danger of increasing nuclear weapons in the world.

Just want to say, I live in Dallas, TX and urban fishing is very much a thing. It #8217;s kind of a fun hobby in and of itself to search around and find the small pockets of water that are fish able. You #8217;d probably be surprised how many you can find in the city. You can use google earth and look around to find various streams and ponds, and as long as they aren #8217;t on private land it #8217;s usually legal to fish there (this definitely varies by state/country so research first).

Chess might not be a bad idea. It has the reputation of a game that requires a lot of intelligence, but it really is just a game. To be a grandmaster you pretty much need to be a genius, but anyone can play casually and enjoy the game. Definitely would fit the category of a hobby that makes you feel smart. There are several wonderful websites to play chess where you are matched up against people of similar skill, and they are mostly all free to use, although they do usually have a premium version (not really worth paying imo).
